WACKER actively participates in the Bradley County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). We work with the Bradley County Fire and Rescue Department to conduct facility familiarization tours for firefighters, support required facility inspections and conduct joint training exercises.

Professional technicians test our fire protection system on a monthly basis, including signals, alarms and sprinkler protection of specified processing areas. Similarly, service technicians perform monthly inspections and service on our respiratory protection equipment, and annual inspections on all fire extinguishers.  Facility personnel test our fire pumps, safety showers and eyewash stations on a weekly basis. Facility personnel also conduct regular testing of the uninterruptable power supply and emergency power generators, which will allow the facility to operate in a limited capacity to maintain process safety in the event of a major electrical power interruption from our supplier. 

Site personnel who are members of the Fire Department participate in frequent training and drills.  They also receive training on emergency response procedures and the proper use of protective and response equipment. The Fire Department will maintain both the chemical protective clothing and response equipment.

F) PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Wacker Charleston continually seeks to improve its processes through advancements in technology and automation. We are continually working to ensure the safety of our site, our team members, our community, and our environment.

D) THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
 The site experienced an incident on November 13, 2020, when a contractor pipefitter applied excessive torque to flange bolts on a heat exchanger outlet pipe containing HCL, causing the pipe to crack and release HCL.  This incident did not result in a release of a regulated substance that met or exceeded a reportable quantity.

E) THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
WACKER staffs a full-time professional Fire Department using highly trained Fire Fighters to respond to all emergencies that may occur at the WACKER site. The Fire Department employs site Emergency Action Plans when responding to any type of site emergency. The Emergency Action Plans take into account different types of emergencies that could foreseeably occur.
In the event of an emergency requiring assistance from outside agencies, WACKER personnel will make all required notifications. The Wacker Fire Department staff, working in conjunction with the applicable local, state and federal agency representatives, will jointly decide on how to ensure neighboring communities and property are protected. In compliance with RMP requirements, Wacker has conducted an Off-site Consequence Analysis and determined that, under some circumstances, a release of a regulated substance could result in off-site consequences.

C) THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
WACKER's general accidental release prevention program incorporates, among others, the following regulations and requirements:
EPA 40 CFR 68 - Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (Risk Management Plans)
OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 - Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals
OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120(q) - Hazardous Waste Operations & Emergency Response (Emergency response program to hazardous substance releases)
Other EPA, OSHA, DOT and State regulations
Recognized and generally accepted engineering practices, codes and standards, and
WACKER Environmental, Health, Safety and Security standard procedures
The chemical accident prevention / process safety management program includes the following
elements:
- Employee Participation
- Process Safety Information
- Process Hazard Analysis
- Operating Procedures
- Process Operations & Maintenance Procedures Training
- Contractor Safety
- Pre-Startup Safety Reviews
- Mechanical Integrity
- Safe Work Permit system that includes Hot Work, Lockout/Tagout, Opening of Pipelines and
Confined Space Entry
- Management of Change
- Incident Investigation
- Emergency Preparedness and Response
- Compliance Audits
The following are examples of engineering and administrative controls in place at WACKER related to control of the regulated substances at the site::
- the regulated substances, in both liquid and gaseous forms, are produced, stored, used and
recovered within dedicated process equipment
- bulk quantities of flammable liquids awaiting further processing are contained

A) THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT THE STATIONARY SOURCE 
Wacker is committed to the Safety, Health and Security of our team members, contractors, visitors and customers, and to our neighboring community. WACKER Charleston continually strives to meet or exceed all applicable Environmental, Health, Safety and Security laws, regulations and other requirements in all of its operations at all of its facilities. At the WACKER Charleston, TN site, we seek to prevent accidental releases of hazardous substances through a combination of robustly engineered equipment, use of proven, highly reliable chemical processes and advanced technology that minimizes reliance on human responses.

WACKER's approach also involves extensive training of our chemical operations team members in the many detailed operating procedures that have been developed. We inspect our facility thoroughly on a frequent and regular basis to ensure that any issues that are found are addressed before they become significant concerns.

WACKER's commitment to protecting people and the environment extends to its approach to
emergency preparedness and response. To ensure that the effects of any releases that do occur
are minimized, Wacker has established a full-time, fully trained professional fire department and
emergency response team equipped with state-of-the-art response equipment.

B) THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
The Wacker Charleston Site is a chemical manufacturing facility that produces hyper-pure crystalline polysilicon for the solar energy and semi-conductor industries. The site operates on a continuous basis, seven days per week. The highly integrated and interconnected process is divided into production units with specific functions that operate independently.
